title: Other than musical ability, what other skills are developed while learning to play an instrument? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve played cello for four years, and I’ve learned and developed many related and unrelated skills: Mathematical reasoningThis one is probably the most obvious. Music is divided as fractions, and in order to correctly count the beats and where the notes go in relation to the beats, you need a where-developed sense of fractions and numbers in general, so you can glance at a measure and immediately know where the beats go and where your notes go. This is especially challenging to do quickly, since rhythm is hard. Social skillsIf you’re playing in a band, orchestra, or other group, you’ll gain a group of people that you’ll be spending a lot of time around. Spending time around people naturally improves your social skills. Additionally, children learning to play an instrument learn how to talk to adults by the need to effectively communicate with directors and private teachers. Music isn’t something that can be learned without questions. There are subtletys that a committed student will want to know about, and they’ll have to ask. Adults gain a similar advantage but not to the same degree as they already know how to talk to people their own age. Concentration skillsLessons, group rehearsals, and practicing all require large chunks of time focused on just the music. Unlike general classes in school, there isn’t work that can be finished, and then time after to fool around and not focus. When you’re playing your instrument, you cannot be distracted, since you need to learn what is best for you playing your music, as well as fixing any mistakes, which will be there. Dealing with frustrationThere will always be mistakes, and when there aren’t mistakes, there are dynamics, and once dynamics are nailed, there’s style, and after that, phrasing and speed, followed by technique. You’re never done, and you can be working on one two-measure sequence for hours on end, trying to figure out what sounds wrong, only to realize that you were playing a C sharp instead of a C natural in one chord, along with counting a beat wrong. Creative problem solvingA forgotten skill in music: problem solving. When playing a solo piece, you have to figure out what exactly you want to convey to your audience, and work that into your piece in any manner of ways. This is how famous musicians get their distinctive styles. When playing in a group, you may have to make modifications to suit what the others in that group are able to play, or change something to make technique a little easier, such as shifting for string instruments. Coming up with these little changes is a skill that quickly improves with practice. ResponsibilityYour instrument, which is expensive (unless it’s a harmonica), needs you to take care of it. If it’s a string instrument you need to wipe it off with a soft cloth from time to time and you can never forget to loosen your bow hair before putting your bow away. The utmost care is imperative to prevent damaging your instrument. If those reasons aren’t enough for you to get started on learning an instrument, I don’t know what would be. Music is a complex, multifaceted art form, and playing in instument is a fantastic way to learn about it.

Hand-eye-ear coordinationIndependence and strength of fingers/hands (and depending on how big your instrument is, sometimes your arms and shoulders too)Development of small muscle groupsCooperation with other peopleSocial skills (bands and orchestras have their own mini culture, and in bigger groups, the sections even have their own subcultures)Depending on how long they stay at the instrument, they could learn enough to teach it themselves. I know many older teenagers who have made some good side cash teaching private lessons to elementary school band kids.Hope this answers your question!
